issues.title: describe composition model(s) in the appendix
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
As mentioned in a few discussions, we need to explain how we expect the claims set defined in this document to be composed with evidence from the platform and workload.

This is heavily dependent on the use case and HW architecture; therefore, it would be non-normative. (This is why it makes sense to relegate it to an appendix.)

Now, a fairly obvious use case is the integration with the Arm CCA token.
We should probably start with that.

Other use cases could be added in the future.

issues.title: Properly Represent CXL device claims
issues.author: mathieupoirier
issues.body: The current specification represents claims for devices using the SPDM protocol on PCIe busses.  Other bus technologies such as CXL may also be used and need their own representation.  This will likely be added as a new "device-claims-set" in da-token.cddl, alongside "spdm-claims" and "pcie-legacy-claims".

issues.title: Add Support for SPDM Challenge Representation
issues.author: mathieupoirier
issues.body: The SPDM Challenge request/reponse can be used to authenticate a device in a CMA (Component Measurement and Authentication) scenario.  This specifiation should include support for that by adding  new "spdm-challenge" to "spdm-claims" in spdm-claims.cddl.

comments.author: steven-bellock
comments.body: The PCIe (6.4) specification is vague on whether a CMA device should support `CHAL_CAP`. We know that it must support asymmetric cryptography and measurements, via the DMTF measurement specification format. As such, for SPDM 1.2+, since the L1/L2 transcript contains `VCA`, then `GET_MEASUREMENTS / MEASUREMENTS` is sufficient to authenticate the Responder. In particular, at NVIDIA we do not implement `CHAL_CAP` on most of our Responders.

comments.author: mathieupoirier
comments.body: The motivation behind adding support for CHAL_CAP stems from [this implementation](https://lore.kernel.org/all/cover.1719771133.git.lukas@wunner.de/) from Lukas Wunner.  The goal is for people with that kind of usecase to use same claims representation.

issues.title: EAT profile chores: Lock down any optional behaviour
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
EAT profiles must clearly define any optional behaviour.

See [Section 6 or RFC9711](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9711.html#section-6.3) for the list of options to address.

See [Section 5.2 of RFC9783](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9783.html#section-5.2) for an example of an existing profile.

pulls.title: Some refactoring and content for measurement claims
pulls.author: mathieupoirier

comments.body:
typographical/editorial note: let’s follow the NSNL convention [1].
It makes diffs much easier to interpret.

[1] https://github.com/cabo/kramdown-rfc/wiki/Manuscript-Style
This is quite a significant change of scope.  What is the reasoning behind this?
Ok, I'll fix this

The DA token CDDL shows how to use the SPDM attestation.  Just like code, I thought it would be best to introduce small parts, i.e the spdm-claims, and then use it in an example.  I am not strongly opinionated on this.

I am not opinionated on how the assembly should look in the end.  However, I quite strongly believe we need to provide an outline of that.
I see two core topics at work in this spec:
1. How to expose SPDM in a user-friendly way;
2. How to use the EAT framework to express attesters' composition in a confidential computing platform that implements some form of device assignment.

The former is 100% bottom-up; the latter needs continuous zooming in and out to ensure it all fits together.

reviews.author: thomas-fossati

Really awesome stuff!

I have inlined a few editorial notes for your consideration.

comments.body:
```suggestion
As such we focus on the formalization of an Evidence format for SPDM compliant devices while leaving room for the definition of other Evidence format such as CXL and CHI.
```

```suggestion
The Device attestation claim consists of an EAT profile identifier, a nonce and any number of individual device claims.
```

“we” is usually banned from cold, impersonal, standard documents :-)

```suggestion
As previously mentioned, this draft defines the claims set for SPDM-compliant devices, while allowing for future expansion.
```

“claims set” is a term of art used extensively in RFC9711.

```suggestion
All the device claims are contained within an EAT submodule ({{Section 4.2.18 of -rats-eat}}).
In the submodule, each device's claims set is identified by a unique name.
The format of the individual claims sets depends on the bus or protocol supported by the device.
```

```suggestion
SPDM measurements start with a component type that reflects one of the 10 categories defined by the SPDM specification.
```

```suggestion
SPDM-compliant devices can optionally support the capability to sign measurements.
```

ISTM, this is a prime case for normative language.

```suggestion
Slot 0 SHALL contain a certificate chain that follows the Device certificate model or the Alias certificate model.
```

IIRC, the certificates are concatenated with no intermediate padding, right?

If so, this should be clearly stated because it impacts the parsing function and, as such, is an interoperability criterion.
There are 4 occurences of "SPDM compiliant" in the text, with only one of them carrying an hyphen.  I removed the sole occurence of the hyphenated instance.
This is not the kind of details that would have jumped at me, though I'm pretty sure I know where in the spec they talk about it.  I will investitage.

comments.body:
I believe this must be expressed more clearly.

Since we are repackaging the information, this is the perfect place to remove variability and define one single transport format that the receiver will have to deal with.

Since each X.509 certificate is self-delimiting, we can just drop any padding and concatenate the certs in a single binary blob.

Editorial suggestion:

> _"[…] a certificate chain comprises one or more DER-encoded X.509 v3 certificates {{!RFC5280}}. The certificates MUST be concatenated with no intermediate padding.”_

pulls.title: Add an optional VCA claim to the SPDM claims set
pulls.author: thomas-fossati
pulls.body: Add an explicit (optional) VCA claim to the SPDM claims-set.

comments.body: Optionally, the Negotiated state preamble (version, capabilities and algorithms) ...

```suggestion
Optionally, the Negotiated State preamble (version, capabilities and algorithms) bytes can be included to present the full negotiated state between the SPDM requester and responder.
```

```suggestion
The Negotiated State Preamble, i.e `vca`, claim contains the concatenation of messages GET_VERSION, VERSION, GET_CAPABILITIES, CAPABILITIES, NEGOTIATE_ALGORITHMS, and ALGORITHMS last exchanged between the SPDM Requester and Responder.
```

```suggestion
The Negotiated State Preamble (i.e., `vca`) claim contains the concatenation of messages GET_VERSION, VERSION, GET_CAPABILITIES, CAPABILITIES, NEGOTIATE_ALGORITHMS, and ALGORITHMS last exchanged between the SPDM Requester and Responder.
```
@thomas-fossati I am behind on this latest spec evolution so forgive me if the question is off - Attesting SPDM version makes sense to me but how can a node prove the SPDM negotiated state?

Hey Dimi!

VCA is the negotiated state _“preamble”_, as defined in [§10.1.1 of SPDM v1.4](https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0274_1.4.0.pdf#page=56).

Essentially, it is the raw capture of the sequence of messages exchanged between the SPDM requester and responder at the beginning of their conversation.

At the request of two vendors, we are exploring the possibility of conveying the value as-is.

This may change in the future.
thank you Thomas for this info

pulls.title: first stab at defining the submod naming scheme
pulls.author: thomas-fossati
pulls.body:
For SPDM, use the `ub-DMTF-device-info` field if it is available in the SAN of the leaf certificate; otherwise, use the RFC4514 encoding of the certificate Subject.

For the time being, I have left this as TODO for legacy PCIe.

I am wondering whether we need to use a namespace for the labels to avoid any possible conflicts.  For example, we could prepend `spdm:` or `pcie:` and similar, i.e. `"spdm:ACME:Widget:1234567890"` instead of just `"ACME:Widget:1234567890”`

Fix #17

comments.body: I really like this enhancement.
I'm not sure this addition adds any kind of clarification.  It seems like something is missing to complete the sentence.
Is it called an "SPDM submod" or "SPDM submodule"?

Maybe that's where we mandate something like "legacy-pcie:anykindofname".  I'm adding the "pcie" part because there might be legacy devices on CHI and CXL as well.  All this is highly speculative - that's what happens when your cristal ball is broken.
Both submod and Submodule are acceptable, but the latter is better.

```suggestion
The name associated with an SPDM submodule is extracted from the leaf certificate of the relevant device.
```

```suggestion
* If the leaf certificate contains a Subject Alternative Name of type DMTFOtherName, the submodule name is the value contained in `ub-DMTF-device-info`.
```
Should we add forward references to the defined "Submodule Naming” subsections (SPDM and legacy)?
I agree with your (broken) crystal ball.  I would extend the explicit namespace indication to SPDM as well and, in principle, to any other bus technology that we want to cover.

I.e., something like:

> _"The syntax of the device name depends on the type of bus or protocol used.  See Section x.y.z for SPDM, and Section a.b.c for legacy PCIe."_
Yes, that would provide a concrete example.
Ok for the explicit namespace indication.  Better to have more information than not enough.  The worse thing that can happen is people asking to remove or change it.
I have addressed this in [5f12ecc](https://github.com/rats-device-attestation/draft-poirier-rats-eat-da/pull/18/commits/5f12ecc4270c194fdd200d8cedddf63cf2784dbb)

```suggestion
The namespace used for legacy PCIe submodules is "legacy-pcie".
```

```suggestion
The namespace used for SPDM submodules is "spdm".
```

```suggestion
For example, "legacy-pcie:0000:01:02.0" where "0000" is the domain, "01" the PCI bus id, "02" the device on the bus and "0" the device function.
```
